item.title: The Mint Hotel and Casino Las Vegas: A Neon Icon of Vintage Vegas
item.description:
A Rising Star on Fremont Street

The 1950s in Las Vegas were a whirlwind of growth and innovation, and no building embodied that spirit quite like The Mint Hotel and Casino. Opening its doors on July 12, 1957, The Mint wasn’t just another casino; it was a statement. Conceived by Milton Prell, Al Winter, L.B. “Tutor” Scherer, and J.D. “Joe” Hall, and managed by the astute Sam Boyd, The Mint aimed to be different, and it certainly succeeded. Its towering 16-story neon pylon, immediately visible for miles, was a bold declaration of Las Vegas’s ambition. Imagine the effect – nearly three miles of neon tubing, and a dazzling 16-foot star beaming up to 30 miles away! This was Vegas showmanship at its finest, a visual spectacle unlike anything seen before.
